docs.lead_paragraph: This was supposed to be the year when a long-sought, long-promised prescription drug benefit was finally delivered to the nation's elderly. Now, crucial lawmakers and health policy experts say, those benefits seem almost certain to be deferred again, like so much else on the domestic policy agenda. The question, for some, is whether the chances of adding drug benefits to Medicare will be much better next year, when Congress could be confronting the brutal combination of a recession, intense budgetary constraints and the pressures of an imminent election.

headline.main: Prospects Dim for Medicare Drug Benefit

docs.abstract: Crucial Congressional lawmakers and health policy experts say long-sought and long-promised prescription drug benefit seem almost certain to be deferred again, like much else on domestic policy agenda; question for some is whether chances of adding benefits to Medicare will be much better in 2002, when Congress could be faced with brutal combination of recession, intense budgetary constraints and pressures of imminent election; comments by Sen John Breaux, important player on Medicare policy, and others noted (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Hungry and Jobless'' (column, Nov. 1): Bob Herbert correctly underscores that those hardest hit by the economic downturn that New York faces after the World Trade Center tragedy are those who have been falling through the cracks all along: the city's uninsured and low-wage earners, a population likely only to grow larger post-Sept. 11.

headline.main: A Safety Net For New York

docs.abstract: Planned Parenthood of New York City aide Joan Malin letter on Bob Herbert's Nov 1 column cites need for low-cost health care for city's low-wage workers hard hit by Sept 11 attacks

docs.lead_paragraph: The Rite Aid drugstore chain has agreed to pay $150,000 in fines to the state to settle a suit over overcharging customers who lacked prescription drug benefits. According to a spokeswoman for Rite Aid, this practice was discontinued in June 1998, when Rite Aid changed management. Rite Aid, which is based in Camp Hill, Pa., has 177 stores in New Jersey. The settlement concludes a three-year investigation by lo sukellthe state Consumer Affairs department. Jo Piazza

docs.lead_paragraph: In August, a poll appeared in this newspaper indicating that New Yorkers, a perennially discontented lot, had reached a possibly unprecedented level of contentment under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Barely a third of the respondents said that they would move out of the city if they could, down from 60 percent 10 years earlier. Only a quarter expected life in the city to worsen over the next 10 to 15 years, which was the lowest such figure the pollsters ever recorded. Though few respondents knew much about the six major candidates then vying to succeed Giuliani, who is barred by law from seeking a third term, the outcome scarcely seemed to matter; nearly two-thirds said they felt that New York would be as good a place to live, or better, under any of them. The city appeared to be running on rails. It seemed, in that remote era, that the next mayor, whoever he was, would inherit a job shrunken back to normal size after the grandiosity and melodrama of the Giuliani years. Listening to the candidates' rather desultory speeches and debates, it was a fair guess the new mayor would retain the core Giuliani program while making symbolic and tonal changes -- no more concrete barriers at City Hall, no more savage mockery of critics -- that would allow him to pronounce an end to the Giuliani Era. New York no longer needed a Big Mayor.
docs.abstract: James Traub article assesses Mark Green and Michael Bloomberg, candidates for mayor of New York, on their fitness to handle two big challenges facing city: largest budget deficit in its history and unprecedented task of rebuilding Lower Manhattan; notes that victor will have to tackle these challenges without enormous reservoir of support Mayor Rudolph W Giuliani has built up among New Yorkers and in Washington over last eight years and especially since Sept 11; says most crucial aspect of next mayor's job will be to preserve tenuous solidarity the city now enjoys, turn it to practical use and provide leadership needed by city vacillating between hope and fear; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: WITH anthrax spores turning up all over Washington, plenty of people are heading out of town. Not those in the drug industry.

headline.main: A Muscular Lobby Rolls Up Its Sleeves

docs.abstract: Drug industry gears up its powerful lobby to shape Bush administration policy on biological terror, and results may well influence public health issues and industry profitability for years to come; industry seeks exemption from antitrust regulations, reduction of timetable for getting new drugs to market for treating ills of biological warfare, and immunity from lawsuits for any vaccines they develop to combat bioterrorism; consumer groups and other watchdogs say industry's cozy relationship with administration threatens regulatory standards on new applications of medicines; say industry's efforts to portray its proposals as patriotic gestures mask effort to increase its image while still protecting its financial interests; note that executives from generic drug companies have been conspicuously absent from any administratoin meetings; graphs; photos (L)
docs.snippet: WITH anthrax spores turning up all over Washington, plenty of people are heading out of town.    Not those in the drug industry.

byline.original: By LESLIE WAYNE and MELODY PETERSEN

docs.lead_paragraph: THE news on the job front has not been good. Employers have cut hundreds of thousands of positions this year in response to the weakening economy, especially after Sept. 11, and there are more reports of corporate retrenchment almost every day. The unemployment rate has risen to 5.4 percent, near a five-year high, and is poised to grow. But that does not mean jobs are impossible to find; you just have to know where to look. Several industries seem immune to the current economic downturn, including health care and pharmaceuticals, education, mortgage banking and security. Many employers in those sectors are regularly adding to their work force, economists say.

headline.main: Personal Business; In the Great Job Desert, Some Hidden Oases

docs.abstract: Job prospects are bright in several industries that appear immune to current economic downturn, including health care and pharmaceuticals, education, mortgage banking and security; many of recent layoffs have been concentrated in manufacturing, temporary services and, after Sept 11, airlines; organizations still plan to recruit on college campuses, but less than they did a year ago; photos; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The battle over who will bear the costs of the destruction of the World Trade Center and who will control the reconstruction of lower Manhattan -- already a full-blown brawl involving legions of lawyers and lobbyists -- is continuing to escalate. On Thursday, lobbyists for Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease on the World Trade Center, and for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the property, helped ensure that a bill passed by the House on airplane security included broad language protecting them from claims by victims of the Sept. 11 attacks and their families.

headline.main: Twin Towers At the Center Of Legal Brawl

docs.abstract: Billions of dollars are at stake in disputes over insurance claims for ruined World Trade Center complex and control over reconstruction of lower Manhattan; lawsuits and legislation will affect victims who lost life or property, their families, insurers, lenders, investors, owners and developers; resolution will involve fragile alliances, conflicting interests and charges and countercharges of hypocrisy; Larry A Silverstein, who holds lease on trade center site, seeks to limit his liability while maximizing obligations of insurers and vows to rebuild structures; photos (M)

byline.original: By STEPHEN LABATON and JONATHAN D. GLATER

docs.lead_paragraph: The titles of the new releases say it all: ''The Trouble with Government,'' ''Disaffected Democracies'' and ''Why People Don't Trust Government.'' This fall a host of new books with a variety of new theories tried to explain a well-established, generation-long trend: Americans' steadily declining trust in government. Then September's terrorist attacks turned prevailing ideas about people's faith in their political institutions upside down, along with so much else. The public's reactions to the events of the last two months have been so extreme and apparently contradictory that they have sent social scientists back to the drawing boards, providing them with a real-life, real-time laboratory in which to measure the complex and often ambivalent relationship Americans have with their government.
docs.abstract: Social scientists pay renewed attention to complex and often ambivalent relationship Americans have with their government; seek to explain generation-long trend of steadily declining faith in government, especially after Vietnam War, as well as turnaround that followed Sept 11 terrorist attacks, when many Americans turned to government and found new faith in nation's institutions; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation, a leading provider of health insurance, said today that its third-quarter profit fell 2.9 percent, as the cost of medical care rose and life and disability insurance claims increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Net income dropped to $270 million from $278 million in the period a year earlier, Cigna said. Its earnings per share increased, to $1.81 a share from $1.74, because the company had fewer shares outstanding. Revenue declined 4.9 percent, to $4.78 billion, as Cigna pulled out of some markets.

headline.main: Net Income Was Lower For Cigna In 3rd Quarter

docs.abstract: Cigna Corp reports third-quarter profit of $270 million, compared with $278 million in period year earlier; earnings per share increase to $1.81 a share from $1.74, because company has fewer shares outstanding (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jobless Rate Rises to 5.4% As 400,000 Are Dismissed More than 400,000 Americans lost their jobs last month, the most for a single month in nearly two decades, and the unemployment rate jumped to 5.4 percent, its highest level since 1996, from 4.9 percent in September. Analysts believe the economy is clearly in a recession and even though they expect the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates in another attempt to stimulate the economy, they say the question now is how deep will the recession be? [Page A1.]
